newsitem.title: INDIA: Fund buying props up Delhi shares hit by politics.
newsitem.headline: Fund buying props up Delhi shares hit by politics.

text.p: Sustained buying by domestic financial institutions propped up Delhi share prices on Tuesday after a sharp decline of the previous session triggered by recent political developments, brokers said.
The Delhi Stock Exchange's sensitive index closed 12.27 points higher at 725.48 points. The index had dropped 7.27 percent on Monday.
Monday's fall in share prices was triggered by the Congress party's decision on Sunday to withdraw its crucial support to the ruling United Front government.

"The recovery in share prices was mostly attributed to huge purchases by state-owned financial institutions which entered the ring with a view to avert any major fall," said Vijay Aggarwal of brokers Mass Financial Services.

News that the government would try to ensure parliamentary approval of the 1997/98 (April-March) budget before a confidence vote in Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda, due by April 11, helped to lift share prices.
"End of settlement period at the National Stock Exchange forced speculators to square their positions and helped lift share prices," said Sanjay Mittal of brokers S.R.M. Securities.
The Delhi bourse closed at 4:45 p.m. (1115 GMT), one hour later than usual, to keep in line with the extended NSE trading session, officials said.
Trade was halted at the NSE after it developed a technical snag minutes before the close.
Reliance Industries rose 3.05 rupees to 261.80 on buying by domestic financial institutions, brokers said.
Bajaj Auto edged up 14.10 rupees to 914.10.
Larsen and Toubro climbed 7.40 rupees to 204.50 on domestic fund buying.
